title: What are some tips on writing fantasy without copying Tolkien? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll copy others here on saying that the first thing to do is read more. If you’re having trouble not copying Tolkien, it’s probably because you don’t have much experience with other types of fantasy. I’ll add Ursula K. Leguin to the list of really great fantasy authors who write nothing like Tolkien. Definitely don’t expressly avoid every single thing Tolkien ever wrote about, though. If you’re reading some of these answers and thinking you have to create something utterly unrecognizable, that’s going a bit too far. The real trick is to make sure everything you write is intentional and you always make it your own somehow. Every time you want to include some kind of common fantasy element or trope, think about why you want to include it—is it because it’s best for your story? Then that’s a good reason to include it. Is it because that’s what Tolkien did? Because that’s what you view as the “right” way to write fantasy? Because you’ve seen it so often that you’ve never questioned it? That means it’s time to change it up, think outside the box, rework it, ask questions about why it’s often been included in fantasy works, look into what inspired it, think about what direction you could take it that’s best for your story, look into other sources for inspiration (African and Asian voices are severely lacking in fantasy!). Or avoid it if you want to… but don’t lose sleep over feeling like you have to avoid it. The main thing is, if you notice yourself answering “yes” to any of the questions at the beginning of this paragraph, to ask questions and brainstorm until you get it to the point where you’re answering “yes” to the question at the end of the third paragraph instead.

Do you mean High Fantasy? Because there are plenty of types of fantasy that don’t really borrow from Tolkien. What Tolkien did was to create his own fantasy world which had a variety of races that were mainly drawn from Northern European mythology. He then created a huge amount of back story and added a couple of races that were his own invention. He also created languages based on European languages. In essence he drew on his own specialist knowledge and created an in-depth world based on that knowledge. He took the time to write something that felt not only like a medieval saga but also real. Now if you don’t want to write like Tolkein then first off, don’t do any research. Then don’t bother with any world building and instead just make things up when you get to a problem. Don’t bother plotting things out in detail. Lastly don’t add your own creativity to the mix. You ought to be able to churn out a fantasy book like this in 3 months, so I look forward to reading it.
